title: Ticket #7339: It should be simpler to test ClassAd(s and) expressions
description:
Mat and I both griped about the clumsiness of using condor_status to test/demonstrate ClassAds and expressions while we were reviewing #7206, and Mat observed that it should be a very short Python script to implement a tool with a much simpler interface. 

classad_eval <ad> <expr>[ <expr>]+

or

classad_eval <ad> <expr>[ <expr>]+

We've decided on classad_eval rather than condor_eval -- even though the tool will evaluate using HTCondor ClassAd semantics -- because classad_eval is less obscure/confusing to the people who don't know the difference, and the people who do won't care.

We want classad_eval packaged as a command-line tool, but in the Python bindings. At least initially, it doesn't have to much behave like a "normal" HTCondor command-line tool, particularly in terms of error-handling.
remarks:
2019-Oct-24 14:13:30 by tlmiller:
Thinking about it a little, I think we can do the following without much more code, and it would make certain expression testing easier: 

classad_eval <expr>

Where having exactly one argument implies that no ad is necessary to evaluate expr.

2019-Oct-24 14:23:30 by matyas:
Not a big fan of changing the meaning of the first parameter based on whether the second parameter is present (aside: Unix cal(1) has a place of honor on my hate list for that exact reason). How about 

classad_eval <expr> [<expr>...]
classad_eval -a <inline ad> <expr> [<expr>...]
classad_eval -f <ad from file> <expr> [<expr>...]

2019-Oct-24 15:58:57 by tlmiller:
After discussion, see child tickets.

2019-Oct-25 08:28:24 by karpel:
Could we use entry_points instead of scripts for packaging? It makes it much easier to test and makes editable installs work.

See https://python-packaging.readthedocs.io/en/latest/command-line-scripts.html

2019-Oct-25 10:50:04 by tlmiller:
"Editable installs"?

But yes, we can do that.

2019-Oct-25 10:52:22 by karpel:
pip install -e <path/to/pkg/dir> symlinks local package source into your Python package directory instead of copying it, so you can pretend like it's installed without having to re-install it every time you make changes (for dev purposes only, really).

2019-Oct-25 18:44:13 by tlmiller:
[58275] implements simplify(), but the lifetime of ExprTree 's return from simplify() is probably tied to the lifetime of the scope argument. I find this moderately absurd even in C++; it's probably flat-out wrong in Python. If a scope argument is not supplied, and the ExprTree has a parent scope, the lifetime of the return is probably the same as the lifetime of the original ExprTree -- which is the lifetime of the parent scope. This is also a model which I imagine will cause infinite confusion. Finally, if the scope argument is not supplied, the lifetime of the return really should be the natural lifetime of the Python object in question.

It may even be more problematic that the answer varies than that it isn't always the natural lifetime of the Python object.

We will have to have to have words with BrianB.

2019-Oct-29 14:58:47 by tlmiller:
We need to document:

  • the new tool
  • that Python's ExprTree.eval() no longer accepts raw dictionaries (wrap them in classad.ClassAd() first)
  • the existence of simplify(), and if we do, that attempts to use a temporary ClassAd, or the resulting ExprTree past the lifetime of the non-temporary context argument, is a terrrible, terrible plan.

2019-Oct-31 12:32:40 by tlmiller:
Also, we need to make sure the new tool:

  • is packaged in the tarballs
  • is packaged by RPM and Deb
  • is packaged by anaconda/pip

... and that it ends up in a sane place, and runnable, in all three cases.

2019-Oct-31 16:35:02 by tlmiller:
Documentation is done.

2019-Nov-12 11:22:25 by tlmiller:
We discussed the packaging problems at Flightworthy; HTCondor will now just require the Python bindings, and we'll "just" install this script into the usual binary directory, not using setup.py at all. (We'll thus have to duplicate or leverage its shebang-line rewriting powers until we can actually drop Python 2 support.)

2019-Dec-20 10:59:44 by tlmiller:
For the 8.9.5 release, we'll just package classad_eval like we do condor_top (in the python bindings RPM/deb, but not in the PyPI/pip/conda package(s)), and not make the Python bindings a hard dependency.
